The ЂOTs-04ї Combat knife
The OTs-04 knife was developed at the Tula Central Design Research Bureau (TsKIB) in the late 80s - early 90s and was intended for special forces of the Interior Ministry troops.
Kukri

This is a special blade made of high-carbon spring-spring steel of the bus, which for many years stood in an anomal field, and therefore has excellent cutting and chopping properties. Ideal for cutting mutants of all stripes, and for protection against them.
AK-12 Monolith

A rare stuff. Modified version of AK-12 2012. Mainly used by the Monolith faction. Has several modes of firing: automatic, single and, three rounds.

AK12 Monolith Upgraded

A rare stuff. Modified version of AK-12 Monolith. Mainly used by the Monolith faction. Has several modes of firing: automatic, single and, three rounds. Thanks to the new trigger group, it is a more advanced and powerful weapon than the original. Increased rate of fire and improved balancing. This is irreversible upgrade.

The version of the AK-12 presented to the public in 2016. It differs quite significantly in appearance and in the design of a number of important units from the previous version of the AK-12 shown in 2015. The design of the machine was revised both to eliminate a number of identified shortcomings and problems, and in the direction of improving manufacturability, taking into account the wishes of the military.

HK USP Match Tactical

This is modification of the HK USP Match specially developed for scientists by the personal order of Professor Sakhorov, designed for use in the "Specialist-Scientist" kit. The operation of the system of mechanisms is improved with the help of artefacts. The difference from the standard USP Match is the ability to install a silencer. The gun is equipped with an enlarged magazine for 22 rounds of 9mm caliber. (The Specialist-Scientist kit includes: BCC Savant, HK USP Match Tactical, Monolith Blade).

 %c[d_purple] Х %c[ui_gray_2] Silencer: AAC Black Box
VSS "Savant"

This is early prototype of VSS Savant. This build is more popular between pro-stalkers because of lower price than final version.

VSS "Merc"

At the request of the Syndicate of Mercenaries, a team of enthusiastic scientists led by Professor Sakhorov was engaged in finalizing the prototype. To develop and conduct field trials, it took about 20 artefacts from gravitational anomalies. As a result, this allowed the Picatini bar to be installed on the receiver without loss of accuracy, as well as improved mechanics, which led to higher reliability indicators..

Monolith's Blade

[RUSSIAN ACCENT "ON"] It is rumoured, these blades are produced in very a few by masters from a groupment Monolith. Threw composition of alloy not known - it is talked to extract him it is possible only in the heart of sarcophagus.[RUSSIAN ACCENT "OFF"]
Saiga-12 "Nerd"

Nerd - is the evidence of the professorТs concern for his wards. This Saiga version was purchased specifically for personnel. Used in "negotiations" with especially dangerous mutants about the transfer of their organs as a gift to science .. Experienced hunters look with considerable envy at the "nerds" armed with this model.

Ruger SR-556

Several of these rifles entered the Zone through scientists. According to legend, Professor Sakharov received 6 small conteiners with these guns from foreign sponsors, but 5 of them were lost during transportation. Ruger SR-556 is an American self-loading carbine manufactured by the arms company Sturm, Ruger & Company, Inc. became the first Ruger of the AR-10 family. Ruger SR-762 chambered for .308. Belongs to a few samples of AR-15 rifles using the removal of powder gases. Production ceased in January 2016 after the introduction of the Keymod Lightweight option.

This AK, a kind of beard venom (not to be confused with his tea). Lightweight and tailored to the harsh conditions of the Zone. Does not provide for mounting a grenade launcher. It is made at Skadovsk and Yanov Station, from where it disperses throughout the Zone.

Used by ISG special units.

SKS Tactical

Molot OP-SKS Carbine is designed for loading with 7.62x39 - the very popular ammunition in Zone. The weight and dimensions make the carbine ergonomic for shooters of any age and height. The tactical option differs from the original in the presence of a mount for installing sights in the fore-end area and also the possibility of installing a silence. Also new light trigger was installed on this model that significantly increased the rate of fire

KS-23

Special carbine, 23 mm - Soviet multifunctional police pump-action shotgun, designed to suppress riots, selective force, mental and chemical effects on offenders. Interestingly, having a caliber of more than 20 mm and a rifled barrel, the KS-23 should not be classified as small arms, but as small-caliber artillery.

A model developed by Kalashnikov USA on the basis of the Komrad 12 semi-automatic rifle for hunting and protecting members of ISG research teams from mutants. The weapon has both a dovetail mount and a picatinny bar for use with various types of sights. This model has a new type of trigger mechanism , which allows you to two rounds burst.

AK-74 PMC

A modification of the Kalashnikov assault rifle, developed in 1970 for the 5.45x39 cartridge. It differs from the standard version by the installed body kit, which includes a tactical grip, a forend with picatinny rails and a folding telescopic buttstock, which significantly improves ergonomics of the gun. The kit also includes a laser targeting device, a tactical flashlight and an adapter mount for sighting devices. In the Zone similar models are usually used by mercenaries, Ukrainian special forces, various PMCs and other power structures for conducting special operations.

AS Val Tactic

The AS Val is widely used by Russian Army recon units, as well as by MVD (Internal Affairs Ministry) and FSB (Federal Security Bureau) Special Forces. The AS-VAL is a gas operated, integrally suppressed weapon. The receiver is machined from steel forging for improved strength. It has a standard side-mounted rail for optical, night vision or red dot scopes but has no provision for mounting a bayonet or a grenade launcher. The integral suppressor could be easily detached for maintenance, repair, or compact storage, but the rifle should not be fired with the suppressor removed due to safety and reliability issues.

VSS Vintorez

Designed at TsNIITochMash by Peter Serdyukov and his team, the new rifle was intended for various Spetsnaz troops of the Soviet Army, KGB and MVD. The VSS is quite popular among its users for its stealthy capabilities and the great lethality of the heavy 9x39mm bullets. The effective range of the VSS is limited to 300-400 metres. Standard sighting equipment consists of side rail on the receiver, which usually accommodates the 4x PSO-1M2-1 scope. Any other scope or night vision sight can be mounted on the appropriate mount. Backup iron sights consist of tangent rear and blade front. The rear sight is graduated for up to 400 metres.

AKS-74U

The AKS-74U was intended for use mainly by Spetsnaz units, airborne infantry, rear-echelon support units and armoured vehicle crews, who require a compact but relatively powerful individual automatic weapon. The AKS-74U is significantly more manoeuvrable in tight quarters than the AKS-74, but a significant decline in muzzle velocity resulted in a decrease in effective range.

M4 Tactical

Colt M4A1 - an assault rifle (carbine), designed in the USA on the basis of AR-15 platform for 5.56x45 NATO cartridge. It was developed primarily for use by vehicle operators and fireteams, who required a more compact and lighter weapon than a standard full-length rifle, but using the same ordnance. However, US SOCOM (United States Special Operations Command) was soon to adopt the M4A1 for all subordinate units, followed by general introduction of M4A1 into service in the US Army and Marine Corps.

DS ARMS SA-58

SA-58 OSW (Operations Specialist Weapon) manufactured by American company DSA (David Selvaggio Arms) is a legal copy of the FAL, its made with the same Steyr-Daimler-Puch production line equipment as the StG-58. It may come with a different barrel length, an aluminum-alloy lower receiver, and improved Glass-filled Nylon furniture. Civilian models are semi-automatic, but military and Law Enforcement clients can procure select-fire models that have a fully automatic cyclic rate of 750 rounds/minute. The DSA-58 can use any metric-measurement FAL magazines.

RPG-7

The RPG-7 is a further development of the previous RPG-2 anti-tank grenade launcher. The RPG-7, in its first version, known as RPG-7V, has been adopted by the Soviet army in 1961, and is still fielded in Russia and at least 50 more countries. By far, RPG-7 can be considered as one of the most successful anti-tank grenade launchers ever made. Initially thought of as an anti-armour weapon, it was later adopted for other fire support missions with the introduction of other types of grenades, such as anti-infantry HE-FRAG and multi-purpose Thermobaric/FAE. The RPG-7 is a shoulder fired, single shot, smoothbore recoilless launcher, grenades are loaded from the front, and the rear of the barrel is fitted with venturi nozzle. Due to the recoilless design, the backblast is dangerous. The RPG-7 is usually issued with 2.7X fixed magnification optical sight, designated PGO-7. It is a simple and inexpensive, but possess a high threat to modern tanks and can also serve in a number of other roles, making it a flexible weapon.

The MP-133 is a product of the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant. This shotgun is an evolution of the earlier IZh-81 pump action shotgun, and is intended for civilian and security markets. It is produced in two basic versions: standard MP-133 with tubular magazine and MP-133K with detachable box magazine, both versions can be in various barrel lengths and styles, wood or polymer furniture, fixed or side folding polymer stock or pistol grip only. The MP-133 shotgun uses traditional pump action with sliding forend that has dual action bars. Locking is achieved by a tilting locking piece, installed in the bolt and engages the notch in the barrel extension when in battery. Feed is from tubular underbarrel magazine that holds 4 rounds, though capacity can be enhanced by installing magazine extension tubes.\n

The MP-153 self-loading shotgun was the first semi-automatic shotgun designed and manufactured by Izhevsk Mechanical Plant. It was developed along with the pump action MP-133 shotgun and shares many parts and assemblies with it. The MP-153 is one of the most popular semi-automatic shotguns of Russian origin, and is widely used to hunt various games in Russia. It is also sold for export, it is known as Remington "Spartan" SPR-453 autoloader in US. MP-153 shotguns are known for solid but somewhat heavy construction and reliability.\n
Gauss rifle

PB
PB (modern)

The PB (Pistolet Besshumnyj or Silent Pistol), also known in the Soviet army as 6P9, has been developed in 1967 for Spetsnaz units of the Soviet Army, as well as for KGB operatives. The pistol is based on a modified Makarov PM pistol and features an unique integral two part suppressor. Issued into service in 1967, the PB (GRAU index 6P9) is a Soviet silenced pistol based on the Makarov PM. It was intended for use by the KGB and army reconnaissance groups. The front part of the suppressor is detachable, so that the pistol can be broken down into two parts for convenient carry. The PB's integral suppressor also reduces the bullet velocity to below subsonic levels.

CAA AK-Alfa

Developed in Israel by Command Arms & Acessories (CAA), the AK-Alfa assault rifle was first presented to the public in 2016. This weapon is marketed under two brands - "Kalashnikov USA" and "Kalashnikov Israel". Apparently, this weapon got into the Zone with the the ISG faction. The AK-Alpha assault rifle is an attempt to improve the ergonomics of the AK rifle while maintaining its main advantages - high reliability and ease of maintenance. The base for the AK-Alpha is the receiver, the barrel with the gas tube, the bolt group and the main components of the trigger of the Russian-made Saiga carbine.

Steyr AUG A1 in standard rifle configuration (military green colour). The AUG is an Austrian bullpup 5.56mm assault rifle, designed in the 1960s by Steyr Mannlicher GmbH & Co KG (formerly Steyr-Daimler-Puch). The AUG (Armee-Universal-Gewehr "universal army rifle") was adopted by the Austrian Army as the StG 77 (Sturmgewehr 77) in 1978, where it replaced the 7.62mm StG 58 automatic rifle (a licence-built FN FAL). In production since 1978, it is the standard small arm of the Austrian Bundesheer and various national police units.

AK 5C

The Ak 5 or Automatkarbin 5 ("automatic carbine 5", "automatic carbine" being the Swedish term for assault rifle) is the Swedish version of the FN FNC assault rifle with certain modifications, mostly to adapt the weapon to the partially subarctic Swedish climate. The Ak 5 is the service rifle of the Swedish Armed Forces. The Bofors Ak 5C is the modernized version of the original Ak 5, following the trend of modular weapons. One of the most significant improvements is the MIL-STD-1913 rail system to which a variety of different optics, lights and sights can be mounted, such as telescopic sights and image intensifiers. The double gas position, iron sights and bolt catch of the original Ak 5 rifle family were discarded.

The M4 Carbine descends from a family of firearms tracing its lineage back to earlier carbine versions of the M16, all based on the original AR-15 made by ArmaLite. It is a shorter and lighter version of the M16 assault rifle, sharing 80% of its parts. The M4 fires 5.56x45mm NATO ammunition and are gas operated, air cooled, magazine fed, selective fire firearms with a 4 position telescoping stock. As with many carbines, the M4 is handy and more convenient to carry than a full length rifle. It has been adopted by United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) and is the preferred weapon of the U.S. Army Special Forces and Navy SEALs.

The AKM is a 7.62x39mm assault rifle designed by Mikhail Kalashnikov. It is an improved version of the AK-47 rifle and was developed in the 1950's. The production of AKM rifles was carried out at the Tula Arsenal and Izhevsk Mechanical Works.

L85 A2

The development of the SA80 system, which included two weapons - the SA80 IW assault rifle and SA80 LSW light machine gun, began in the late 1960s when the British Army decided to develop a new rifle, to replace the ageing 7.62x51mm L1 SLR British made FN FAL. The standard individual weapon for the British armed forces, the L85 (in its original A1 version) had numerous performance issues. The A2 variant came to be as the result of a significant upgrade in the early 2000s by Heckler & Koch and remains in service as of 2020. L85A2 is extremely reliable over a range of climates for various operational scenarios. The current L85A2 rifles are recognised as reliable and accurate, especially when using standard issue SUSAT telescope sights.

Korth 4" Barrel

Korth is a high-end firearms manufacturer based in Lollar, Germany. For some gun aficionados, nothing more needs to be said. Builders in the tradition of ultimate European luxury brands, Korth are perhaps best known for revolvers with price tags that most people would find easier to associate with German cars than German guns. But that out-of-this-world pricing reputation which is the stuff of gun counter lore world wide is derived from their full custom stuff; the entry point is far more accessible. The starting point for a Korth is around the starting point for a Rolex: five thousand dollars will put some of that European goodness in your hands, and it will sure be memorable. Korth guns are legendary.

Howa Type 20

The assault rifle was officially unveiled to the public in May 2020. This weapon is intended to replace the Type 89 assault rifle, which has been in service for about 30 years. The new rifle of the Japanese Self-Defense Forces, like the previous one, was developed by Howa Machinery Co, and uses 5.56 mm ammunition. The development of a new rifle to replace the Type 89 began at the request of the Japanese Armed Forces in 2014. Externally and structurally, the new Type 20 rifle is a kind of arithmetic mean of many modern rifles, such as the HK433 or CZ BREN II, and, apparently, does not have any original features. However, there is nothing wrong with this, since it is not the originality of the design that is required from the army weapon, but reliability, low price and compliance with the customer's requirements. It remains a mystery how and in what quantity this rifle came to the participants of a scientific expedition to the Zone.
